text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data’s ​Peer Review Framework for Predictive Analytics in Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Response​ aims to create standards and processes for the use of models in our sector. The Framework
label: BODY

text: consists of five steps: model submission, technical review, implementation plan submission, ethical
label: BODY

text: review, and final report. The output of the model submission is a completed Model Card that includes
label: BODY

text: information about the intended use, model development, model evaluation, and operational readiness.
label: BODY

text: For further information, please contact Leonardo Milano: ​leonardo.milano@un.org​.
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model - October 2020
label: BODY

text: Model Summary
label: HH2

text: Organization developing the model: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data in collaboration
label: BODY

text: with the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL).
label: BODY

text: Model date:  Official release on 28 October 2020
label: BODY

text: Model version: V1 - October 2020
label: BODY

text: Model type: Spatially distributed SEIR model
label: BODY

text: License: ​MIT​ License
label: BODY

text: Main contacts:  Leonardo Milano, Predictive Analytics team lead, UN OCHA Centre for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data leonardo.milano.un.org
label: BODY

text: Link): ​GitHub Repository​ and ​Methodology paper
label: BODY

text: 1.  Intended Use
label: HH2

text: In-scope use cases: what is the actual and potential scope of the model? Describe the
label: BODY

text: situations in which the model output is expected to be reliable.
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky model is a COVID-19 metapopulation compartment model initially designed to
label: BODY

text: estimate medium-term (on the order of weeks) case incidence and healthcare usage at the second
label: BODY

text: administrative (admin-2, ADM2) level. These ADM2 regions are all coupled using mobility information
label: BODY

text: to approximate the inter- and intra-regional contacts between the members of the populations.
label: BODY

text: The model is therefore expected to be reliable for short to medium term projections in all situations
label: BODY

text: in which data is available to tune all the model’s parameters.
label: BODY

text: Out-of-scope use cases: what are the model’s limits and constraints?
label: BODY

text: The OCHA-Bucky methodology is not expected to be applicable for estimating:
label: BODY

text: Spread and patterns at a very granular level (city, neighborhood, refugee camp, etc.). Other
label: BODY

text: models such as Agent-Based Models are expected to be more reliable in these situations.
label: BODY

text: Non-human-to-human communicable diseases. The main transmission route simulated by
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky is based on contacts between people.
label: BODY

text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: Describe the situations in which the model output may not be reliable?
label: BODY

text: The main know limitations of the model are linked to:
label: BODY

text: The lack of data to tune the model parameters. In absence of such datasets, the model could
label: BODY

text: be tuned based on assumptions but the ​projections will depend on them and should be
label: BODY

text: interpreted accordingly​. The main inputs to OCHA-Bucky are:
label: BODY

text: Subnational historical COVID-19 cases and deaths data to tune the reproduction rate
label: BODY

text: Subnational age-disaggregated population data
label: BODY

text: Data on non-pharmaceutical interventions currently in place or planned, as it
label: BODY

text: impacts the projected reproduction rate
label: BODY

text: Contact matrices estimating the social mixing of different age groups
label: BODY

text: Location-specific vulnerability factors which may impact the severity of symptoms or
label: BODY

text: the mortality.
label: BODY

text: The time horizon of the projections. Given the very dynamic nature of the situation, the
label: BODY

text: model assumptions change over time. The model has been used so far to produce four week
label: BODY

text: projections at the national level and two week projections at the subnational level.
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky could be used to explore longer term trends but the ​results should be
label: BODY

text: interpreted as a scenario exploration/comparison tool and not as a quantitative model​.
label: BODY

text: D. Model interpretation: what does the output represent?
label: BODY

text: Model output consists of future projections of geographically distributed COVID-19 cases and deaths,
label: BODY

text: as well as severe cases (defined as a proportion of total cases). Moreover, the model projects the
label: BODY

text: impact of implemented Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions (NPIs).
label: BODY

text: 2.  Model Development
label: HH3

text: Details of the datasets used to build the model.
label: BODY

text: - Describe the sources of data, size, and scope of the datasets.
label: BODY

text: For a detailed description of the input datasets and their use in OCHA-Bucky please refer to section
label: BODY

text: 2.3 in the ​OCHA-Bucky methodology paper.
label: BODY

text: These are the datasets needed to run OCHA-Bucky’s projections:
label: BODY

text: Population Data: Administrative boundaries shapefiles at the ADM2 level from the
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX)​ and the  United Nations-adjusted ​WorldPop​ age and
label: BODY

text: sex-disaggregated population raster data.
label: BODY

text: Vulnerability Parameters: the fraction of the population in an ADM2 region that is particularly
label: BODY

text: vulnerable to COVID-19 is estimated by calculating the proportion of the population affected
label: BODY

text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: by the following  factors:
label: BODY

text: Food insecurity: Food insecurity data is obtained from the ​Integrated Food Security
label: BODY

text: Phase Classification (IPC)​ Global Platform
label: BODY

text: Indoor air pollution - indoor cooking fuels. Data on the use of solid fuels is obtained
label: BODY

text: from the ​World Health Organization​.
label: BODY

text: Mobility Data: Road density data from Humanitarian ​OpenStreetMap (HOTOSM) ​is used to
label: BODY

text: estimate the strength of the connection between all ADM2 regions considered.
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Cases and Deaths: In most countries of interest, the source for COVID case counts is
label: BODY

text: the nation’s Ministry of Public Health. Additional federal (ADM0) historical data is also
label: BODY

text: obtained from the WHO.
label: BODY

text: Contact Matrix: Contact matrices quantify how much people from different age groups
label: BODY

text: interact, and are extracted from ​Prem et al​.
label: BODY

text: Non-pharmaceutical Interventions (NPIs): For each country, an initial list of NPIs was
label: BODY

text: obtained from the ​ACAPS COVID-19 Government Measures Dataset.
label: BODY

text: - Is it representative of the population being sampled?
label: BODY

text: For the population figures and vulnerability estimates, we largely rely on data collected by partner
label: BODY

text: organizations directly in the countries that we are modeling. The population data obtained from
label: BODY

text: World Pop is compared and adjusted to match the population figures used for Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Response Planning. Vulnerability parameters may not be up-to-date. For each indicator, we look for
label: BODY

text: the most recent and reliable data.
label: BODY

text: - How accurate or reliable is the training data?
label: BODY

text: One of the main inputs to the model is the historical cumulative number of COVID-19 cases and
label: BODY

text: deaths. This dataset is used to tune the parameters of the model related to disease transmission.
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky partially corrects for the known gaps and reporting delays in the COVID-19 data
label: BODY

text: reported by the authorities in the following way:
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky uses recent data to estimate the fraction of cases expected to be reported and
label: BODY

text: corrects the projections to account for large underreporting observed in these countries.
label: BODY

text: Rather than explicitly including a parameter controlling the transmission rate, Bucky uses
label: BODY

text: the recent historical data to estimate transmission at the local level.
label: BODY

text: - How is missing data treated? (e.g., exclusion, single imputation, multiple imputation)
label: BODY

text: Missing data is generally related to the number of cases and deaths at the subnational level. We deal
label: BODY

text: with it in the following ways:
label: BODY

text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: Parameters extracted from national level data (mainly the Doubling Time and the Case
label: BODY

text: Reporting Rate) are applied at the ADM2 level when the information for calculating them at
label: BODY

text: the local level is missing or insufficient.
label: BODY

text: We apply a rolling average, typically with a 14-day rolling window, to smooth out
label: BODY

text: fluctuations in the input datasets.
label: BODY

text: What are the model assumptions and approximations?
label: BODY

text: Like most of the SEIR models, OCHA-Bucky assumes that:
label: BODY

text: Disease transmission is happening exclusively via human-to-human contacts
label: BODY

text: People that recover from the disease will be immune and therefore cannot be reinfected
label: BODY

text: As we are focusing on short to medium term projections we assume birth rates to be
label: BODY

text: negligible
label: BODY

text: The severity of severe symptoms and covid related deaths are assumed to be dependent on
label: BODY

text: people’s age and vulnerability factors. The impact of COVID-19 on access to healthcare
label: BODY

text: facilities is not simulated in OCHA Bucky.
label: BODY

text: Death rates from causes other than COVID-19 are also assumed to be negligible within the
label: BODY

text: timeframe considered in the simulations.
label: BODY

text: Methodology - provide a description of the different analysis steps and how the input
label: BODY

text: datasets are used to train the model.
label: BODY

text: The OCHA-Bucky model consists of a series of adjustments to an existing COVID-19 model
label: BODY

text: (JHUAPL-Bucky) that was developed as part of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Mathematical Modeling Forecasting Ensemble.
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky is a collection of coupled and stratified SEIR models. Since COVID-19 exhibits heavily
label: BODY

text: age-dependent properties, wherein a majority of severe cases are in older individuals, SEIR models
label: BODY

text: are stratified via the age demographic structure of a geographic region to obtain accurate estimates
label: BODY

text: of case severity and deaths. Additionally, to model the spatial dynamics of COVID spread, we
label: BODY

text: consider a set of SEIR sub-models at the smallest geographic level for which we have appropriate
label: BODY

text: data. For a full description of the methodology please refer to the ​OCHA-Bucky methodology paper.
label: BODY

text: 3.  Model Evaluation
label: HH2

text: Are there other similar existing models and how does this model compare?
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky is a subnational implementation of a broad class of SEIR models that have been used to
label: BODY

text: project the impact of COVID-19. In the United States context, the parent model (JHUAPL-Bucky) is
label: BODY

text: included in the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) COVID-19 ​Mathematical Modeling
label: BODY

text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: Forecasting Ensemble​.
label: BODY

text: The figure below highlights some of the features of OCHA-Bucky which makes it more adaptable to
label: BODY

text: humanitarian contexts.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1: features of OCHA-Bucky making it adaptable to humanitarian contexts.
label: BODY

text: Have there been any past peer reviews, such as published papers or other review exercises?
label: BODY

text: The model hasn’t been published in a peer-reviewed journal yet.
label: BODY

text: Is there any reference or benchmark used to evaluate the performance?
label: BODY

text: The Bucky model has been validated using U.S. case data. The validation has shown good agreement
label: BODY

text: on daily figures with no significant model bias. Some noise on daily case & death counts, especially
label: BODY

text: at small numbers is observed.
label: BODY

text: The OCHA team is currently working on the validation of the OCHA-Bucky in Afghanistan and
label: BODY

text: potentially other humanitarian contexts.
label: BODY

text: D. What are the metrics used for model evaluation? Why have these metrics been selected?
label: BODY

text: Describe current model performance.
label: BODY

text: The model has been evaluated by looking at residuals between projected and actual cases on
label: BODY

text: historical model runs. The figure below shows the validation of the JHUAPL-Bucky model in the U.S.
label: BODY

text: Most of the data points lie within the estimated model uncertainty band and no significant bias is
label: BODY

text: observed.
label: BODY

text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: Figure 2: validation of the JHUAPL-Bucky model in the U.S. Most of the data points lie within the
label: BODY

text: estimated model uncertainty band and no significant bias is observed.
label: BODY

text: How does performance depend on forecast lead time?
label: BODY

text: The reliability of the projections decreases with lead time. The main factor having an impact on this
label: BODY

text: is not a limitation of the methodology used but rather the dynamic nature of the disease. At the
label: BODY

text: beginning of the outbreak, COVID-19 was spreading in an uncontrolled way in many countries
label: BODY

text: resulting in a high reproduction rate (a measure of how fast cases are growing). As governments
label: BODY

text: implemented mitigation measures to slow the spread of the disease, the reproduction rate dropped.
label: BODY

text: Long term projections couldn’t capture this evolution. We suggest using OCHA-Bucky for projecting
label: BODY

text: cases and deaths up to four weeks out. The model can however be used as a scenario exploration
label: BODY

text: tool (i.e. not as a quantitative model) for longer lead times.
label: BODY

text: What is the risk tolerance of the model? What happens if the model produces false positives,
label: BODY

text: false negatives?
label: BODY

text: Inaccuracies of the model are limited in the following ways:
label: BODY

text: Projections are limited to four weeks at the national level and to two weeks at the
label: BODY

text: subnational level.
label: BODY

text: Every time a new model run is performed, the disease transmission parameters are
label: BODY

text: recalibrated from recent data.
label: BODY

text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: Uncertainties are calculated by varying most of the model parameters within uncertainties
label: BODY

text: (Monte Carlo simulation).
label: BODY

text: Projections are always presented as a range which covers the projection uncertainties.
label: BODY

text: 4.  Operational Readiness
label: HH3

text: Is the model ready to be used to inform humanitarian response?
label: BODY

text: -Is the model kept up-to-date with the latest datasets?
label: BODY

text: Yes, the Centre for Humanitarian Data is updating the input datasets and the projections on a regular
label: BODY

text: basis. Based on the projections reports are produced and shared with the OCHA country offices and
label: BODY

text: other stakeholders. All the reports can be accessed ​here​.
label: BODY

text: -  Who is responsible for model updating and/or recalibration?
label: BODY

text: The Predictive Analytics team of the OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data.
label: BODY

text: -  Is the model ready to be deployed? If not, what are the additional steps needed (e.g. further
label: BODY

text: research, validation, updates)?
label: BODY

text: The model has been already deployed and used at different levels to better inform COVID-19
label: BODY

text: response strategies.
label: BODY

text: Has the model been developed in collaboration with operational partners? Has the model
label: BODY

text: previously been used in humanitarian situations?
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky is the first model fully developed by the Centre. The Centre acted as an intermediary
label: BODY

text: between OCHA field offices and the JHU team of technical experts. The model projections are
label: BODY

text: available for six countries: Afghanistan, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Iraq, Somalia,
label: BODY

text: South Sudan and Sudan. Since July 2020, we have worked with OCHA colleagues and partners in
label: BODY

text: these locations to finetune the model with country-specific data. Currently, the reports are shared
label: BODY

text: with the field offices in these six countries.
label: BODY

text: What happens if the model is inaccurate, produces false positives or false negatives?
label: BODY

text: Describe expected impact according to the in-scope use cases highlighted in Section 1A
label: BODY

text: above.
label: BODY

text: The main risks for OCHA-Bucky are related to the underestimation and the overestimation of
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 cases. Underestimation of cases could potentially lead to a response that is not adequate
label: BODY

text: MODEL CARD: OCHA-Bucky COVID-19 Model
label: HH1

text: to the actual impact of the outbreak. Overestimation of COVID-19 impact may lead to ill-informed
label: BODY

text: allocation of resources and prioritisation. Some of these biases are due to the poor quality of the
label: BODY

text: input data. These risks are mitigated in the following ways: i) by reducing the lead time of the
label: BODY

text: projections and by updating them as frequently as possible; ii) by presenting the results together
label: BODY

text: with a clear description of the assumptions and the corresponding uncertainties and iii) by inviting
label: BODY

text: partners not to rely solely on the model projections but use it as additional evidence to support their
label: BODY

text: decisions.
label: BODY

text: D. List additional considerations for the use of the model in humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky has been initially developed to inform COVID-19 response but it can be potentially
label: BODY

text: adapted to other human-to-human infectious diseases (e.g. influenza, measles, polio, ebola). The
label: BODY

text: team is currently working on extending the model to include vaccination scenarios in the
label: BODY

text: projections.
label: BODY

text: OCHA-Bucky’s code and documentation are publicly available and interested partners can use it to
label: BODY

text: run their own simulations. For more information and support please contact the Centre for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data ​centrehumdata@un.org​.
label: BODY
